intro: Andryala lyrata var. ramosissima, commonly known as the fragrant sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, clustered leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces delicate, five-petaled flowers in shades of white, pink, and purple, typically blooming in spring and early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it well adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Its aromatic foliage and showy blooms make it a desirable plant for xeriscaping and native gardens.
